captions.text: Not only is your throat too tight to breathe,
No, you aren't being stalked by a monster,
a fate some deem worse than death.
See, when you're dead, you feel nothing;
at a podium, you feel stage fright.
But at some point we've all had to communicate
so you have to try and overcome it.
To start, understand what stage fright is.
Humans, social animals that we are,
are wired to worry about reputation.
"What if people think I'm awful and I'm an idiot?"
That fear of being seen as an awful idiot
from a primitive part of your brain
It's the fight or flight response,
a self-protective process seen in a range of animals,
most of which don't give speeches.
But we have a wise partner
in the study of freaking out.
Charles Darwin tested fight or flight
at the London Zoo snake exhibit.
against the imagination of a danger
by the nuances of modern civilization.
So, to your conscious modern mind,
To the rest of your brain,
built up to code with the law of the jungle,
when you perceive the possible consequences
it's time to run for your life
Your hypothalamus, common to all vertebrates,
triggers your pituitary gland to secrete
Your neck and back tense up,
as your muscles prepare for attack.
to maximize the delivery of nutrients
and oxygen to muscles and vital organs,
so you get dry mouth, butterflies.
it's hard to read anything up close,
This isn't all in your head.
It's a natural, hormonal, full body reaction
by an autonomic nervous system on autopilot.
And genetics play a huge role in social anxiety.
John Lennon played live thousands of times.
to feel more scared performing in public.
Since stage fright is natural and inevitable,
focus on what you can control.
in an environment similar to the real performance.
Practicing any task increases your familiarity
so when it's time to speak in public,
Steve Jobs rehearsed his epic speeches
If you know what you're saying,
you'll feed off the crowd's energy
convince your body it's about to be lunch
has had millions of years more practice than you.
Just before you go on stage,
Stretch your arms up and breath deeply.
so take that last minute to stretch and breathe.
You approach the mic, voice clear,
Your well-prepared speech convinces the wild crowd
And to the fact that no matter

title: The science of stage fright (and how to overcome it) - Mikael Cho

comments.author: Mash Button Jr

comments.text:
Does your stage fright mainly consist of "what ifs..?" For me I use to 
drown my self with "what if I fall of the stage.."what if I forget line" 
what if I crack? " untill I started to do what I call "thinking the what 
ifs through" for instance.... "What if I forget a line.. Then I will do me 
best to recover and move on in life" after doin this I realized that there 
is nothing I can do on stage that will ruin my life for ever!!! Go to my 
channel and find the video "HOW I NEVER GET STAGE FRIGHT" to discover how I 
have compleatly destroyed my own stage fright through a list of simple easy 
tips!! Good luck!!❤️❤️
comments.author: Lindsey Austin

comments.text: Amazingly made!﻿
comments.author: Nomi Nami

comments.text:
I can really relate to this video. When i step up infront of an audience 
it's like something takes the control away from me. I can't speak 
correctly, my vision gets blurry, my whole body is tingling and my hands 
can't even for a moment try to stay still.
And after I've struggled through those few minutes and my speech is done, I 
sit down in my seat, and I can't even remember what i just did.

It is truly an awful feeling, to not have control. But this video made me 
determined to tame the animal inside of me. ﻿

comments.author: Joshua Kim

comments.text:
Last time I had to do a presentation my fight or flight response was to 
shake of the nerves, speak clearly, make eye contact, etc. all were 
positive reactions. Normally fight or flight responses are to run away from 
trouble, and during my presentation I wanted to run away from all the 
negative reactions I usually have by acting normally. My grade was on the 
line and I saw performing normally as my only way out. Not to mention all 
the odds were against me, I was unbearably hungry and sleepy, yet I kept it 
together. God is so good, I believe my strength comes from him, especially 
during presentations! ﻿
comments.author: Fictionista

comments.text:
Wow you are very brave! I have had one to many presentations where I let my 
nerves get the best of me ...Does your stage fright mainly consist of "what 
ifs..?" For me I use to drown my self with "what if I fall of the 
stage.."what if I forget line" what if I crack? " untill I started to do 
what I call "thinking the what ifs through" for instance.... "What if I 
forget a line.. Then I will do my best to recover and move on in life" 
after doin this I realized that there is nothing I can do on stage that 
will ruin my life for ever!!! Go to my channel and find the video "HOW I 
NEVER GET STAGE FRIGHT" to discover how I have compleatly destroyed my own 
stage fright through a list of simple easy tips!! Good luck!!❤️❤️

comments.text:
I would just like to point out that a TED Talk is supposed to be on a 
professional level, and when you have spelling errors in your subtitles, it 
can be very frustrating. Take the time to proofread your stuff, a single 
spelling error makes your whole presentation look bad. 

Breathe: to breathe. To take in breath. 

Breath: Air that has been inhaled and will be exhaled. 

There is an e at the end of the word breathe.

Spelling is important.﻿

comments.author: PentaMaker

comments.text:
Absolutely true. I've given many public speeches, from small rooms to 
hundreds of people. You NEVER lose stage fright, but you can get used to it 
and control it. And the best way to do so is to stop fighting a pointless 
fight, accept that it's there, but don't let it overpower you. And take a 
deep breath.
comments.author: Tom NixNachname
